title: 106_s2310
content: The Act titled "Firearms Dealer Penalty Flexibility Act of 2000" allows for the suspension of a firearms dealer's license and imposes civil penalties. Section 923 of title 18, United States Code, allows the Secretary to suspend or revoke a license or impose civil penalties up to $10,000 for willful violations of firearm regulations. The Secretary can also suspend or revoke a license or impose a civil penalty for the transfer of armor-piercing ammunition. Additionally, the Secretary has the authority to compromise, mitigate, or remit liability for any willful violations. The Secretary has the authority to compromise, mitigate, or remit liability for willful violations of firearm regulations. If the Secretary denies a license application, revokes or suspends a license, or imposes a civil penalty, written notice must be provided stating the specific grounds for the action. The Secretary has the authority to compromise, mitigate, or remit liability for firearm regulation violations. If the Secretary denies a license application, revokes or suspends a license, or imposes a civil penalty, written notice must be provided stating the specific grounds for the action. An appeal process is available, including a hearing upon request, and a decision can be appealed if not reversed. If the Secretary decides not to reverse a denial, revocation, suspension, or penalty, the aggrieved party can file a petition for judicial review within 60 days. The aggrieved party can file a petition for judicial review within 60 days. In the judicial proceeding, the court may consider any evidence submitted by the parties, and if it decides that the Secretary was not authorized to make the denial, revocation, suspension, or assessment, the court shall order the Secretary to comply with the judgment. Upon petition for judicial review, the court may order the Secretary to comply with the judgment if it finds the denial, revocation, suspension, or assessment was unauthorized. The Secretary must stay the effective date of any suspension, revocation, or assessment upon request pending an appeal. SEC. 3. Amends Section 925(b) of title 18, United States Code, to terminate a firearms dealer's license upon felony conviction.
